intro: Agrostophyllum gahavisukae, commonly known as the Kauaʻi false hibiscus, is a rare flowering plant native to the Hawaiian island of Kauaʻi. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its showy, five-petaled flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded forest understories, often in areas with high humidity and well-drained soil. It is notable for its unique floral structure and is considered an endemic species, highlighting its ecological significance to the Hawaiian flora. Due to habitat loss and limited distribution, it is also listed as endangered.
